name: C General Library
tagline: You've heard of the C standard library, but have you heard of the C General Library? This library is a work in progress, and adds extensive functionality and reduced development time to any C project. The library contains implementations of some of the most basic data structures and algorithms, including utf8 character objects, strings, graphs, heaps, stacks, sets, queues, priority queues, trees, and much, much more. This library also allows you to set your own memory allocators and deallocators, as well as your own thread handlers.
body:
# C General Library This library was developed to assist in writing high performance C based applications quickly. 1. [Getting Started](#getting-started) 1. [File Setup & Compilation](#file-setup) 2. [Library Context](#library-context) + [Default Setup](#default-setup) + [Custom Setup](#custom-setup) + Memory Allocators & Deallocators + Customized Data Containers 2. Data Structures & Algorithms 1. [Unicode and Strings](#unicode-and-strings) + Unicode + Strings 2. [Stacks, Queues, and Priority Queues](#sqpq) + Stacks + Queues + Priority Queues 3. [Lists and Vectors](#lists-and-vectors) + Lists + Vectors 4. [Sets](#sets) + List-Based Sets + Vector-Based sets 5. [Trees](#trees) + Binary Search Tree + Balanced Trees | AVL + B-Trees + Tries 6. [Maps](#maps) + Maps + Hashmaps 7. [Graphs](#graphs) + Getting Started with Graphs + Graph Structure + Breadth-First Search + Depth-First Search + Weighted Graphs + Edge Masks + Finding the Shortest Path | Dijkstra 8. [Sorting Algorithms](#sorting-algorithms) + Sorting Algorithms Overview + Mergesort + Quicksort + Heapsort + Bucket Sort 2. Data Formats 1. JSON + Intro to JSON + JSON Object Structure + Creating JSON Objects + Parsing JSON Strings 2. XML + Intro to XML + XML Structure + Creating XML Objects + Parsing XML Data 3. Graph Data + Serializing General Library Graphs + Loading Serialized Graphs 3. Mathematics 1. Number Generators 4. Type & Function Reference
# Getting Started All the information you need to get up and running.
##File Setup & Compilation In order to use the general libraries, you must first copy the lib folder (as part of the project root) within the source directory of your application. Once you've copied the folder, you can include the main general library header, genlib.h (Individual header files exist for individual library components as well. We'll get to that later).. #include "lib/genlib.h" //Include the main general library header. int main(int argc, char* argv[]){ return 0; } Jumping ahead, once you are ready to compile your source code, you must include the pthreads library. For example, using gcc, you would call: gcc project.c -pthread -o [executable name]
##Library Context The C General Library utilizes a context object which contains all the data pertaining to the current instance of the library, such as: + Memory Allocation + Memory Deallocation + Logging + Error Handling + Instance Identification + External Data A defined context is required for using the functions within the library. You can create a new context by generating a new variable of type _**standard_library_context**_, like so: #include "lib/genlib.h" //Include the main general library header. int main(int argc, char* argv[]){ //Create a new library context. standard_library_context ctx; return 0; }
###Default Setup The standard library provides extensive customization with regards to how memory is handled, logging is accomplished, errors are accounted for, and the encapsulation of external data. In many instances, you may want to apply the default configuration to the library context. By using the default configuration, the library will use calloc() as the memory allocator, free() as the memory deallocator, and all errors and logs will be printed to the console. In order to initialize the context to the default configuration, simply call the _**_std_lib_default()**_ function. #include "lib/genlib.h" //Include the main general library header. int main(int argc, char* argv[]){ //Create a new library context. standard_library_context ctx; //Initialize the context to the default configuration. _std_lib_default(&ctx); return 0; }
###Custom Setup While using the default context configuration often good enough for a number of projects, many developers may opt for more control over the behavior of the library. For example, you may be building a software package for an embedded system requiring precise control over memory allocation and error handling. You may even be including the library as part of a large, multi-threaded or multi-process application, and want to create a new context for each thread or process in order to monitor said thread or processes memory consumption.
